para.paratext: Under O.C.G.A. § 24-8-821, parties can use admissions contained in pleadings of an opponent “[w]ithout offering the same in evidence.” Such admissions in judicio bind the party so that they cannot put up evidence over objection to contradict such admissions, unless the admissions are properly withdrawn.[1] A proper amendment that does not incorporate the prior allegations prevents the prior admission from becoming a binding admission in judicio.[2] A judicial admission is conclusive and cannot be denied or disputed.[3] “However, if a party amends its pleadings to withdraw the admissions, it may then introduce evidence contravening the admissions. If such contradictory evidence is admitted, even over the objection of the other party, then … such evidence may be deemed to amend the pleadings to withdraw the admissions.”[4] Importantly, only admissions of fact, not opinion or conclusions of law, may be considered as evidence under this rule. For instance, an admission that a party executed a personal guaranty does not mean that the party admitted the legal effect of the guaranty.[5]

The Georgia Court of Appeals held that it was reversible error for a trial court not to allow the plaintiff to cross-examine the defendant about admissions in the defendant's answer without first putting the entire answer in evidence.[6] The text of the Code section refers to “pleadings,” but it may also be applicable to a statement of facts included as part of a summary judgment brief.[7]
On the other hand, exhibits attached to a complaint[8] and affidavits attached to a brief for summary judgment are not judicial admissions.[9]
Generally, a stipulation of facts is only conclusive in that case, but it may also be properly introduced as an admission in another case between the parties that involves the same issues.[10]

To be binding, a judicial admission must be one of fact and not merely a party's opinion or conclusion as to law or fact.[11] Thus, an answer to a complaint which states as an affirmative defense that the defendant executed a note as an accommodation party is not a binding admission of fact which would support a summary judgment order. In Gunter v. Hamilton Bank of Upper East Tennessee,[12] the Georgia Court of Appeals reversed a summary judgment against the defendant based upon such an admission. Similarly, in Flynn v. Mack,[13] the court held that the plaintiff's admission that there was slight evidence supporting the jury's verdict against her was an opinion on the facts and not an admission of fact and did not constitute an admission in judicio.

A defendant's answer in a complaint to modify custody that the defendant was a resident of Colorado effectively divested the Florida court that originally rendered the divorce decree of jurisdiction and acted as a bar to the defendant's motion to dismiss.[14]
Lynchar, Inc. v. Colonial Oil Industries, Inc., 341 Ga. App. 489, 801 S.E.2d 576 (2017), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 303 Ga. 839, 815 S.E.2d 917 (2018).

A. S. Wikstrom, Inc. v. Norair Engineering Corp., 156 Ga. App. 49, 274 S.E.2d 28 (1980), held that an affidavit of a party on a motion for summary judgment could be introduced for impeachment, but it is not an admission in judicio and the party may testify to the contrary.
SAKS Associates, LLC v. Southeast Culvert, Inc., 282 Ga. App. 359, 638 S.E.2d 799 (2006).

Taxi company's admission that the driver was its employee, given in its initial answer to a negligence action filed by a passenger, could be withdrawn by timely amendment, since admission was not contained in a verified pleading or otherwise given under oath. Lopez v. El Palmar Taxi, Inc., 297 Ga. App. 121, 676 S.E.2d 460 (2009).

Luther v. Clay, 100 Ga. 236, 28 S.E. 46 (1897); Hawes v. Nashville, C. & St. L. Ry. Co., 223 Ga. 527, 156 S.E.2d 455 (1967).
See Aiken v. Department of Transp., 171 Ga. App. 154, 319 S.E.2d 58 (1984).
Also, the statement must not be an opinion as to the legal effect of facts. Scott v. Jefferson, 174 Ga. App. 651, 331 S.E.2d 1 (1985).

Admission in statement of facts on summary judgment that the plaintiffs breached the contract did not constitute an admission in judicio as it was a legal conclusion or opinion and not an admission of fact. Bollers v. Noir Enterprises, Inc., 297 Ga. App. 435, 677 S.E.2d 338 (2009).
Gunter v. Hamilton Bank of Upper East Tennessee, 201 Ga. App. 379, 411 S.E.2d 115 (1991).
